name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: Philosophy

transcript.content: Hello, I'm Ricky Gervais. Philosophy is the science which considers truth. So said Aristotle, one of the great forefathers of Western philosophy. In its attempt to seek out the truths and principles of human existence, Philosophy must answer questions of beauty, of justice, of language, indeed, of the mind itself. To help me consider some of the core concepts and presumptions of philosophical inquiry, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, graduate of the University of Warwick, an award-winning writer.
It's a pleasure to be here.
And Karl Pilkington, a man with no education, didn't really go to school, no awards, head like a fucking orange, you know the twat.
Alright?

To me, philosophy might be the greatest subject of all academic subjects. The mother of science, asking the big questions: Why are we here? How do we live? But it's been sort of mugged and kidnapped by those people who put rubbish under the umbrella of Philosophy, Cod Philosophy. I went to a library once. I looked in the Philosophy section, and there was a book by Doris Stokes.
Doris Stokes being, for those that don't know?
A medium who said she was talking to the dead as crystals. Feng shui. Oh, God.

The interesting thing about Feng shui is how I remember someone came into an office I was working at once, and she said, "You're going to need crystal here above the laboratory to get all the negative chi out of the system," And she said, "This crystal is Â£25," and then I said "I'm not going to spend that," And she went, "Okay, Ive got one for five."
Brilliant.
It was surprisingly convenient that she had a number of different crystals that apparently did the same job.
We also need a brush to get the shit out of the toilet. What have you got for that?

Yeah, there's a lot of that twaddle. There was a woman, I remember once, I used to do a radio show on the BBC World Service, and she came in and she could tell from the coloured liquids, that you chose from a big selection of coloured liquids. She could tell a lot about your personality from that. So, I picked up about three or four and she looked at them and I chose like a blue one, just arbitrary. And she looked at me and she said, "Okay, I get the sense that you like to communicate with people, but on a global level."
Ricky laughs
You're working for the World Service.

As we spoke, we were broadcasting on the World Service. I don't know, she just read it from the liquids. As a novice, one of the key catchphrases, if you like, of philosophy, and one that's always intrigued and confused me a little is the famous Rene Descartes quote: "I think, therefore I am." A lot people think of that as the epitome, in a way, of a philosophical statement.

First thing we ever did, I think, at degree level, and it's the one thing I'd already heard of. It's one of those things that sort of filters down Cogito Sum, as you say, "I think, therefore I am." When Descartes was pondering his existence just before we get to his conclusion. Karl, how do you know this isn't a dream?
Uh,
Just because I haven't been sleeping that well.
Ricky and Steve laugh.
No, no.
Okay.
But you could still be dreaming, couldn't you? Because this could be a dream that you haven't been sleeping lately. You could be dreaming the last few nights you haven't been sleeping.

Eh ... In dreams the - the different - like - I mean, like I say, I don't have that many of them because I don't sleep that well. But when I do have one, there's something different and vivid about it. Now, if I was dreaming all this, I reckon my boiler would have been fixed ages ago.
Ricky and Steve laugh.
I don't think anyone has a dream that goes on for that amount of time.

Well, it could be a nightmare, but the presumption - but I think you're also presuming that the dream that you could be dreaming needs to be exactly the same as the dreams you think of when you're dreaming. What my point is, there's no way of you knowing that this life you're living now as you talk to us is real and that it's not actually the imaginings of another Karl somewhere else.
There are actually no clues, Karl. There are actually no clues now that this is the real thing.
Well, sometime - most of the time it's: one minute I'm awake, next minute I'm asleep. Then I'm awake again.
Yeah.
Sleep's just ...
You know the bit between you being awake and awake again? That - that's called 'asleep'.
Yeah.
Now, do you ever think things while you're asleep?
Vivid things.
It's that bit between the awake and awake I wanna look at.
I told you about one ages ago where ...
Go on.
... where you burst in and I was on the toilet.
Steve laughs.
I never heard this dream.

Yeah, yeah, the one - it was all - it was li... - everyone was German and it was at some gig or something, and you opened the door and everyone was looking and laughing at me, and I'm sat on the toilet and you sort of said "oh, that's probably because you're uncomfortable with ..."
Fame.
"... being put on the limelight".
Yeah, that you might be - uh, yeah, possibly, yeah.
But, that's one dream that _could_ be true.
See, I ...
Ricky laughs.
Exactly!
Or, there is a likelihood that you think: "I bet he's going to burst in".
I am always on edge when you're about, when I use the toilet here. I kind of think: "is he busy at the moment?".
Ricky laughs.
You have to wait till he's on the phone to go for a piss.
I have to sit there holding the lock.
Yeah.
Ricky laughs.
It's a weird thing to do.
I mean, it isn't normal. It's not normal.
Ricky laughs.

But there's an example of a dream. But I think what you're failing to grasp is not so much ... the mechanics of whether this is a dream, but that you cannot know the truth of what you're experiencing; you cannot know that this is reality.
Karl sighs.
It's a question about reality: "Can we know what reality is?".
So let's go onto that then. What - what reality is, and what we like about reality.
Robert Nozick did this thing ...

If you could go into a flotation tank and you led a whole virtual life and it was the best life possible. You did exactly what you've always wanted. You became the person you wanted to be. You did the best things you could ever dream of doing, and you literally couldn't tell the difference. So it was your life, okay? And you lived your biological life out in that tank and died at 80 and had the best life any person could ever have. You could preprogram it. Would you get into that tank knowing what you know now, knowing that you would have the best life ever with no heartache, no upset, no - no loved ones dying.
So what's happening when I'm sort of having a packet of Munchies?
Yeah
Am I having them or are they imaginary?

They're imaginary, but you can't tell the difference, it's the best packet of Munchies you've ever had. I love the fact that you went into the flotation tank and your one proviso was "Are munchies as good?"
Yeah. Absolutely
No, I'm just taking it back to basics.
That is basic.
Right, you've got to pre-program your life, that's where you'd start, is it? Munchies must always taste magnificent.
Well, if you can still enjoy the basic things in life, then that's when you can't go wrong.
You do. You enjoy them. It's the life you'd ever want to live, and you're living it.
Bit dangerous that.
Bit dangerous? Why?
Sorry? Why, go on, why?

Just, uh, I don't know, because sometimes I think things don't happen for the best, right? Sometimes you can sort of think, oh, I'll enjoy that if that happens. And then it doesn't happen, and you've had time to think about what would have happened-

Oh but this is perfect. No, this is built in. Because whatever happens is for the best. So not only when you're in this floatation tank are you enjoying yourself, that things just keep getting better or staying as good -
So you never have a bad day?
You never have a bad day.
But how long would that last for before you go, "I'm fed up with this"?
Well, why would you get fed up with it? Because you do something else. It's the perfect life.

Bear in mind, you're not aware that you're in the flotation tank. You've made that deal but then once you're in there, you're not aware of being in the flotation tank. You're living your life, and it's perfect. You're happy. Well, we don't know how you would be happy. You'd just have munches every day and...

Well, get in it then, get in it. If you don't know you've got in this tank, if I somehow go to bed at night, someone injects me in the head, and then they go, "Right, stick him in the tank now." And then I wake up, packet of munchies there, sun's out. Uh, Suzanne goes, "It's a nice day. You want to go and do something nice?"
Right-
I'll go, "You're meant to be at work." She goes, "No, I don't have to go in today, I'll be, "All right, let's go out then."

Right, now what's interesting there is that, within this scenario, I gave you any life, you could do anything, and you chose the exact life you've got now, except Suzanne's got a day off. Now, I both love that and-
Well, I was a bit suspicious, though, that she's just taking a day off willy-nillyly.

No, wait. It's not happening now. It's not happening, really happening. You can do anything you like. But I like the fact now you're even question it. You're not in the tank. And why has Suzanne got a day off? Right? Now, I love that because that suggests to me that you're a nice, happy, satisfied, whatever you want to do it, contented person, who's got the perfect life. However, it's almost like you haven't fully understood the possibilities. For example, you wake up, there's the Munchies, sunny day, Suzanne's not at work. You go, "Why aren't you at work?"
Eh, half a day off.
She goes to you, "Oh, hold on, why are you flying?" And you go, "I just can." But you hadn't even thought of that maybe you could fly, or swim, or hold your breath.
He's just going to have some Munchies for breakfast.
Hold on a minute. This is day one.
Oh, okay.
When you go on holiday.
Yeah.
Like I said before, you don't turn up and go, right, it's 01:00. Jet ski for half an hour, bungee jump in 40 minutes after that, let's have a nice Roti, and try a little cocktail.
Yeah
And what do you do? What do you do when you ride there?
When you get there?
Yeah.
The fella takes your case to the room
Right
You have that panic of "Am I going to give in too much money? I don't know the currency well enough yet, I don't know how much things are."
More information than we asked for.
Yeah.
The most mundane scenario I've ever heard!
No, but this is what happens in real life.
Right, okay.
So you have that scenario. You go "Right, where's me shorts?" You get them on, you go out and have a wander... You have a wander round to know where everything is. The shop-
The car park you did once!
The shop. You know, how close the beach is, is it busy?
Yeah.
Okay, you're just telling us what happens when you go on holiday, what's your point?
Because you don't want fun all in one go. You want to build to it, because that's sometimes part of it.
Right? Okay. So anticipation, good. Yeah.
That little bit. It's about things taking time innit, then looking back at the journey and going "How did I get here?"
Okay, can I ask a question? Sorry. What I'm fascinated to know is, if you decided to sign up to the float tank idea, okay, you can design your perfect life...
But I prefer not to know I'm doing it.
You won't know! You won't know!

But I won't ask this question: Imagine Ricky and I are the doctors, okay? We can put you in this tank, all we need to know from you now is what your perfect life is. We're going to program it in the computer. You're going to wake up tomorrow, you won't know this conversation's happened, you'll have the perfect life. If you don't mind, we're going to take notes now, what is the perfect life? You're still obviously living with Suzanne...
We've got Munchies, and we've got sunshine.
But what else would you like in your magical life of the ultimate life?
I think I prefer...
Hair?
No, because then I'd know it's not real.
You wouldn't. You would never know.

No, it just came back! Suzanne comes in one day and goes "Why aren't you working?" She goes "Okay, I've left my job, can we leave the 'Why am I [not] at work?' I'm always going to be here!" Right? I've got a new tonic, right, from Boots. She pops it on your air. Boop! Baby gorilla.
Yeah, I don't like this idea of suddenly Suzanne's never at work...
Ricky & Steve laugh
I just think you need a bit of the badness to have the goodness.
Right.
Right.

In a minute you're going to be injected in the head, you're going to go to sleep, you're going to be in a flotation tank, but you are going to suddenly leave this office and it's going to be a virtual world. You can do what you want. You can suddenly go "Why was I hanging around with that bloke off The Office for? I'm a spy!" And you go to MI5 and they go "Thanks for coming in, Pilkington. Listen! Droskie, he's coming from Russia and he's got the--" Bang! What do you do? What's your scenario? What do you do as a job? We've got Munchies, Suzanne's never at work-
I prefer to leave everything as it is...
Brilliant!
Right?
Go in it, but have everything the same so that I'm going "Hang on a minute! Has it actually happened?"
What are you talking about?!
No, you don't know about this! You don't know anything that's happened.
No because you've just said, you're going to put me in the tank and you asking questions as to what I won't want when I get in it.
No. No no no.
No, but you won't know you're in the tank.
Once you're in the tank, you won't know. You'll have a new life. A life that you've designed.
You could have different memories if you wanted. You could be five again or you could be now, but you weren't born in Manchester.
I prefer it to be the same with the same memories, but the difference is when I next get British Gas round, they go "Hi Mr. Pilkington... Yes, the boiler is fixed."
(laughs) Oh god! So he's liked to have a virtual life so his boiler's fixed!
No, no. No no no.
So the boiler still goes wrong in your dream, but it gets fixed.
But you don't even need a boiler! You could be the perfect temperature all the time!
Yeah but this isn't going to be Earth anymore. I don't like the idea of too much change. I don't want that much of a change to me life.
But you won't realize- It won't feel like change!

Well, it's changed already! You're saying the boiler has been fixed like that. (snaps fingers) I prefer to stay of that problem, go "Hang on a minute! Is this different?" Suzanne is still going to work...
Right? (laughs) He wants her to go to work!
That's very important too. You don't want her around all day.
But then- But then, things happen that wouldn't have happened in this world.
Go on then. Okay, let's see the differences. What do you do? Because I've got to program this, so you've got the same job, all that... Are we still around?
Yeah, because it's part of-- Part of the same thing.

I'm gonna ask you a question now: Do I still squeeze your head every time I see you, wrestle you to the ground and wind you up and try and stress you out, call you all hours... Do I still do all that? What am I like?
You're still the same, and you still do that. But maybe one day I go "Don't do that anymore, because it does annoy me!" And you go "Okay!" And then-
He stops
I've dealt with it. I've sorted that problem, as opposed to this machine, this tank deciding.
Right?
I don't like the idea of this tank making life good for me. I want a few problems and this is a problem, I want to sort it.

Okay. We've hit the nail on the head there -we're going to go back to this because it's fascinating- but Nozick concluded that no one would get into the tank. Because we'd rather have a real life with all its problems, than a fake life. And I sort of think you've proved that by even getting into the tank with your provisos and scenarios. I mean, you've changed nothing, except your boiler being fixed and me stop squeezing your head now and again.
But hang on a minute
Which makes me think that you should have your boiler fixed. And then you will have the perfect life that you can imagine.
Yeah, but it's that old chestnut, innit? It's the thing of, like... What's my problem then?
Right?
You've got the problem gene in your head. You've got to fill it with a problem.
Yeah... He's not a geneticist!
(laughs) No
Got the problem hole in your head.
No...
"Got the problem hole in your head" Shut up, Ricky! Let him say what he needs to say!
He said it! He's got a problem hole in his head. It's called his mouth.
Yes
Right, that is your problem hole.
So if someone comes up and they go "I fixed your boiler."
Sorry, can I just ask-
NO! LET HIM SPEAK FOR G-!
Let's me ask one question, Steve. Is the problem hole different from the problem gene? Or is that a new term for-?
No, you put things through the problem hole and they end up in the problem gene. You feed something in the problem hole...
Is that right, Karl?
Yeah!
It goes through the problem tube into the problem gene.
Okay. So it's down the problem conduit. Okay, go on then, right. So it's better to have-- You've got a problem hole in your head.
So you stuff in a problem into the problem hole.
Okay?
Now all the little problems can't get in because of the big problem, right?
Right. Is that good or bad?
But that's not true, is it?
The problem hole is a standard size on everyone.
Right
Shut up! Ricky, let him explain!
Now, Ricky... I'd say his problems are not even problems.
How big is his problem hole?
Same size as mine.
Same size as yours?
But his problems are all little ones. They're like-- You've got, like a load of Skittles, I've got a big Creme Egg.
Right, but why-
Shut up! Let him speak his-- He's just expanding on his idea, why do you keep interrupting?
But what is his problem? What is your problem that's so big compared to my little Skittles?

Loads of problems! You get stressed out about things that I'm like "What's up with you?!" You get annoyed easily with stuff. People chewing loudly, or someone breathing loudly, or someone coughing. Whereas I'm like, that doesn't matter. Like I say say to you, the boiler... he's like "Get it ripped out, put a new one in!" It's not as easy as that.
It is!
And that's why the problem.. ball is growing.
(laughs) He's got a gene, a ball, and a hole!
So the problem ball-
It's no wonder there's no fucking room for a brain!

Right. Shut up! Let me ask- I want to clarify this. The problem ball exists in life. It gets bigger and bigger and bigger. It has to go through the problem hole, down the problem tube, into the problem gene.
Bouncing into the problem gene.
Right. Now then, now then. So you've got the problem ball. Everyone's problem hole is the same size.
Everyone's
But some people's problems are smaller, so they can slip straight to the problem hole...
I've got a question, Stephen.
Wait, wait!
Listen! Has anyone got a pair of problem balls? Or it's just-
Could ladies have a pair of problem balls?
Because Hitler had one problem ball, didn't he? But could anyone ever have a pair of problem balls, is my question to you.
And some of those problem balls are much bigger than other ones.
Yeah, depending on the problem.
So you could have a pair of problem balls and one problem hole.
The way I see it...
Okay, suppose I came to you and I said, "Listen..."
A man starving in a foreign country, might have huge problem balls.

He might have. But if I went to a doctor and said "I've got a problem hole." And the doctor said "Well, let me see it." And I, you know, he said "Let me see your problem hole." And hanging down in front of my problem hole was a huge pair of problem balls... What would he treat first, is my question.
Would he look into the problem hole?
He said, right-- "Take your problem jeans off!" I want to see your problem hole clearly.
Ahh...
But he would fish- He would put his hand or his finger into the problem hole to try and remove the problem ball, wouldn't he?
Well, he could feel the problem balls, but he'd have to insert his finger into the problem hole, wouldn't he?
Right.
Okay, so... Karl, go on then!
I'll just get in the tank!
Ricky laughs
Oh, god!

Okay, so in a roundabout way, back to 'Cogito ergo sum', "I think therefore I am". Descartes, pondering how do I know this isn't a dream? Well... He concluded he doesn't. When he took it further to "How do I know I even exist?" he quite rightly concluded that, "Well, if I'm even pondering this question, I must exist. Whatever I am, wherever I am, the fact that I'm questioning, introspecting, thinking at all. I think, therefore I am. Because I'm even thinking, at least I know one thing: that I exist." That's all he said, Karl.
I don't.
I don't understand why he had so much time on his hands to be worrying about this. At the end of day get on with it!
You're not doing shit-all, Karl!
Ricky laughs

So why are you so annoyed at other people who aren't doing anything? You're just going out in the morning, you're staring at worms. At bugs. You're staring at the sky, wondering why it hasn't fallen on your head...
You're writing books that you're making up! You're making up the books, that isn't researched!
What do you mean, making it up?
What is it that you're doing?
One of the chapters in your book about travel was Australia: "I've never been there myself." Forget it then! Throw it away!
Because you can still have thoughts on it.
You make up stuff about a grub eating a biscuit, "we're all the same", I mean, what is that?! That's not- But! I laughed.
Yeah!
So I enjoyed that book.
Listen, everyone like me, who's bought that book-
That book is absolutely pointless!
It's in my lavatory... Every time I pop in there for a shit, just take it off the shelf, have a little read. Great fun!
Yeah. I'm down to about four pages! Sometimes we have to get bog roll. But listen! That is a fun book to wipe your arse with!
Yeah! It's a great book to wipe your arse with!
That book was good for me. I don't know if anyone enjoyed it... But I was emptying me worry hole.
Ricky & Steve laugh
He's got a worry hole and a problem hole!
You were emptying your worry hole?
Hold on! Is that different to the problem hole, your worry hole?
It's next to it.
(laughs) "It's next to it!"
Once a problem ball is being processed through the hole-- Is it deposited through the worry hall?
Oh Christ!

All I'm saying is... You're right, I do watch a lot of insects and stuff. And you never see them wasting time. They're always doing something. An ant's carrying something somewhere. Sometimes I watch it and it goes somewhere and comes back again, and you think "Does it know what it's doing?" But at least he's trying!
What is it doing, though? What is that ant doing>
Work! He's doing- He's building a house or...
But what's the point? Everything it does is pointless!
How can you say that?
It's pointless!

I tell you what: If there was a bigger sort of being, looking over the world and they went "Right, let's look at the human race!" And well, they'd look at the ants first and they'd go "Right, they've got their hands full. They carrying big stuff. They try to save time by carrying stuff that's way too big for them, really. They could do that between three of them, but they don't. They're all grafting hard." Then they go "Right, hit the human button!" They hit the human button, they watch the humans. The amount of people who are just sat about, doing nought...
But hold on!
Amy Winehouse, Lily Allen in London at 02:00 a.m. So what? What are you doing?!
Ricky laughs
I agree with you. But what are you doing?!

You see, the ant analogy -joking aside- I think there you hit on the fact, that life is about working for what you get. And I'm right behind that! I am right behind that. I think that's absolutely true.
That's what I meant. What's dangerous is...
A boiling kettle to ant
...At the end of the day, right...  -Yeah, but that's evil. Innit?
What?

You know, I don't- You sometimes make out as if I'm an evil man. We've had an ant problem. In the garden. Suzanne said, we got to get rid of these. And I said "Well, that's a bit out of order, they are outside." She said "Yeah, but there's getting a lot of them." She went and popped the kettle on. I said, I can't handle this. I went in, right?
Alright?
Why? You didn't want to see the ants burned? That's sweet. They're dear.

Yeah. They might be causing a problem, but I don't want to see this, this, mess. Now, the thing is, she went out, she poured the hot water on it. I left it a few minutes. I went out. I had a cup of tea, I thought, it's a waste of electrical as well. So I took me cup of tea out there, and I'm sat there and then I just saw one come back from wherever it had been. One ant. He looked devastated. Because that had been away, as far as that was concerned. It had been out to get a leaf or whatever, came back, devastation. It's that- what- That's the thing, it summed up death for me, that. The ants are dead, they didn't know anything. Suddenly they were there, next minute, load of water, dead. It's the people who are still living in life, that are the saddest, aren't they, after death.
Yeah.
And that summed it up.
What do you think do you-
That ant would have been better off being there when it happened.
How could you tell the ant was devastated?
I mean, they run around in circles anyway, don't they? But this was just kind of going, "What's going on?"
And what, did it slow down when it got nearer the nest? Did it drop the leaf, and then you see it run the last few inches?

It just kind of got close and it was like, a double take almost, almost like, it got near the hole and then it was like, "Wait a minute this can't be it, because no one's around." Then it walked on and went, "No, it is the hole", and it went back and it just sort of stopped for a minute.
Ohh
And that for me, that's the sort of thoughts Descartes should have been having.
What...

Things that you can look at as a human and appreciate it, and understand it and go, "Yeah, that's true. That is like life." Instead of, "Oh, am I awake? Am I asleep or what?" Well, you may as well be asleep because you're doing nothing else.
Oh, God! Descartes, Winehouse, Allen -
Slammed
Slammed
What do you do towards enjoying your life?
I don't normally enjoy the thing when I'm doing it, it's after. It's like that holiday, when I was on holiday.
What do you mean, "You don't enjoy the thing when you're doing it, it's after"? What's an example of not enjoying the thing at the moment but you do after?
You didn't enjoy the holiday?
Say like the holiday, I've just been away -
So you've enjoyed coming off holiday.
I want to hear it, you enjoyed the holiday, you didn't enjoy the holiday?
When I'm there, I had fleas biting me.
Yeah
I had mosquitoes biting me.
Yep

There was a funny smell of damp in the bathroom. I was worrying, getting in the sea, thinking, is there stone fish in here? Right? Now you've got all that going on. When you get back, you forget about the damp smell -
Well you haven't.

You forget about the fleas because the bites have gone, they're not as much of a problem. So then your brain starts going, "Well, hang on, what did I enjoy?" And you go, "I enjoyed the dorado fish I had, that I've never eaten. That's an experience." At the time I wasn't enjoying it because I'm thinking, "When I get back, I'm gonna have fleas on me again."
Yeah
So you remember all the good stuff. It's like an old person, when they're dying and they go, "I'm having flashbacks." They don't say, "I'm remembering the time me shoes were too tight.
What did they say?
They're having nice, they're going, "Oh, I loved the time with that...
...I was wearing flipflops.
No, they enjoy, they have flashbacks of their nice holidays.
About what? What do you think you'll look back on?
The holidays, and that, they'll go "Oh, The lovely hot summer of '79."
So you don't enjoy anything you enjoy, while you're doing it...
At the moment. At the moment in time-
I don't understand that! I mean, that is the oddest thing I've ever heard!
I think there's actually a medical term for it, someone who's unable to enjoy-- To receive pleasure, to take pleasure.
It's really weird, that. That is really weird.
No, because you're busy doing the thing. You haven't got time to enjoy...
So you can't enjoy something you're busy doing? Because you're busy doing it, you can't possibly enjoy it?
Or you don't know if you're going to enjoy it, because it hasn't finished yet.
Well, Karl, but listen! I know from the moment-
Right, say this: Bungee jumping. I'd love to be able to do it, I bet you get a brilliant feeling, as you're falling.
Right. Yeah.
But I won't be enjoying it because I'd be going "Is the thing going to snap?"

Right, okay. Well, there is something about that. Extreme sports, there is a reason why you do it, it is the after-effect you enjoy, because it's the fear and then the endorphins that rush to you and you go "Oh God, I survived. Isn't it brilliant?" That's the feeling of euphoria. So that's--
No. You're having a nice dinner.
Right, okay.
Now, when I get a menu given to me in a restaurant "I go, right, what am I going to do here?"
Yeah
Right. Well, when I came here, I thought I'd have some lamb chops. They've got lamb chops, great. I wonder how much they give you, because I quite fancy this pudding they've got.
Right
Now I have the lamb chops, it comes with extra veg. I eat it, I enjoy it. The pudding I wanted, it's gone out the window, I've got no room for it now.
Yeah
But you enjoyed the lamb chops!
You enjoyed the lamb chops, you enjoyed-- You can only get packed so much-- If you're enjoying all your life, all the time, there's no point in regretting anything.
That's just greed!
No, but I was looking forward to the pudding.
Well, you shouldn't have eaten all the veg!
Yeah but I was enjoying it at that point.
But then you take the pleasure that you had at that point.
No, because I wanted a pudding.
You didn't want a pudding or you would had a pudding.
No, because I would have had it for the sake of having it.
I don't know what the whinge is there! You had a lovely meal, you had some lovely lamb chops, you enjoyed the hour-
Because when I read that, they had like, profiteroles on there
Yeah
I said "I fancy a couple of them."
Yeah
And the chance's gone, I'm probably not coming back to this restaurant.
Yeah, but you haven't missed the chance, you had the chance, you didn't want to take it, because you were full of lovely lamb. What's the problem?
It's not like you didn't enjoy the lamb of the veg. If you've not enjoyed that, I can understand your point. But you had a lovely time eating the lamb and the veg! Along with the gravy...

If someone sai-- If the bloke came here and said "You can have the profiteroles if you eat this lamb you don't like." You go "Oh..." and you ate the lamb, you didn't like it, but now you're full, then you could whinge! You wish "I hadn't been forced to eat the lamb and have a lovely bit of profiteroles." That's you know...
I had a spicy sausage.
Ricky bursts into laughter
Right?
Now, the problem was, I was enjoying it, but I thought "This is the spicy sausage I've ever eaten!"
Right?
Now, I could only enjoy that the next day night...
The next day night?
...When I knew that it's gone through the body, there hasn't been a problem. So I go "That was a nice sausage, I'll have one of them again."

(laughs) "That was a nice sausage!" But then the next time, surely you'd be enjoying it! Because you wouldn't have the trauma of the next night, because you'd live through it, and now you just enjoy the lovely spiciness and the sausagyness of the spicy sausage.
Yeah, but the problem is, once you've enjoyed something, it's very difficult to replace what you got from that spicy sausage the first time.
Then why are you looking forward to having another one?
Because, let me tell you.
Go on.
Auntie Nora.
Yeah
She's guilty of this all the time.
She loves a spicy sausage.
I've told you, she prepares all the food. She's got them all in bags in the freezer. Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday.
Right

She's got it all there. Now, what she normally does, she makes a big pot of curry. She goes "What I'll do: I'll pop that in the Monday bag and I pop it in a Thursday bag." It's the same curry. Now she has it on a Monday. She loves it. She thinks "I got the mix just right there, the spices are good, the chicken was tasty."
Yeah
"I'm looking forward to Thursday."

"I'm looking forward to Thursday. I can't wait for Thursday." I'll call her up on the Thursday evening. I'll go "How was the curry that you had on Monday that you said you're having again on Thursday, that you enjoyed?" Didn't enjoy it. "Why is that?" "Don't know. Just not the same." Now the weird thing there is, it is the same. Auntie Nora, that is the same! It's from the same bag, it's from the same pot. But she was expecting too much. And that's the problem. If I had that spicy sausage again, it's never going to live up to it. So forget the spicy sausage! I've had it, I've experienced it. If someone says-
So you'll never have another one?
Well, it depends...
So you won't have anything twice ever?
Maybe not.
Jesus...

But this is insane, Karl! Aside from you, and your Auntie Nora -and presumably all the other Pilkington clan, are all as weird as one another- Why you phone her up and ask her what she's having for tea, I don't know... (laughs)
(laughs) Yeah, that's one thing!
Not only on a Monday, but what you're gonna do on a Thursday as well, I'll make a note of it in the Auntie Nora food diary!
That's proof that you really aren't enjoying your life enough.
Exactly!
To go "Right--" Oh fucking hell...
But what else do you say to old people?
But then he's phoning her up again, later on a Friday, to find out how the Thursday curry went down.
I know, exactly! Yeah. Unbelievable. Just read a journal!
That's two calls that week.
No, it makes her happy, doesn't it, Getting a call. She's got nothing else.
The curry doesn't, the curry didn't make her happy.
No, it did the first time.
Now the question is, is it better to enjoy something once and not again, than not at all?
But you're an idiot because you're the only person who experiences this.
But that's not the choice!
That's not the choice. That's not the choice for normal people. "You can either NEVER enjoy something, or only enjoy it once!" You can enjoy things loads of times!
No, you can't!
That's what a hobby is! A hobby is enjoying things over and over again.
I haven't got a hobby, have I? That's why. I've had loads of hobbies in the past: I did the dancing, I did the boxing, I did... what else have I done?
That is it I think.
But that's what I'm saying. I'll soon get bored. And it's like how you enjoy-- You know, I love Munchies, but I always enjoy the last one more than...
But that doesn't make sense! That goes totally counter to your argument.
No, because it's from one packet.
What?
It's from one packet.
What difference does that make? The first one's still your favorite.
Hold on! So if you do have one Munchie-- I'll go "Here's a Munchie, mate" You go "I'm not going to take one, unless I can have all of them, particularly the last one."
No... I'd like to have them all, please.
No, no. You can't have them all! Don't be so greedy! Have one Munchie. Have the first Munchie, there you go.
Then I'm gonna have one and I'm going to get a taste for them, and I'll probably want another.
Well no, they're my Munchies though, aren't they?
Forget it!
So you'd rather have no munchies than one Munchie?
I'll go and buy a pocket. I'd prefer to go "Do you know what? I fancy a pocket of them!"
But why do you enjoy the last-
Okay
Why do you enjoy the last Munchie more than the first? Whereas you enjoy the first curry but not the last curry?
Because I know that's the last one.
Because you know that's the last one?
No, because I'm eating them all in one sitting. I'm not going "That's for Monday, that's a Tuesday, that's for Wednesday." I'm talking about a packet of Munchies.
Right
I eat them. There's probably about twelve in a packet.
Okay
I shove the first four in without even thinking what I'm eating.
Greedy bastard!
Ricky laughs
(laughs) "I shove the first four in!"
"Without even thinking what I'm eating?"
Now... When you're getting towards the end, you make them last more. You might bite the top of them. You look what's inside them. You go "I'm liking this!"
But hold on! Every time?
What, every time you buy a packet of Munchies?
Yeah.
Yeah.
So hold on though! You must enjoy a packet of Munchies regularly then?
Not as often as you'd think.
I don't know! It's not what I think, I don't know! So tell me how often do you enjoy packet Munchies.
Normally after... sort of every once a month.
So, every month you look forward to every packet Munchies. And the same experience, you get at the end.
Yeah but at the end, I like the last one.
The only thing you know you enjoy, look forward to enjoy, and it fulfills all those expectations, is a fucking packet of Munchies once a month. Fuck me! What do you think happiness is?
Again... You only know the happiness, because of the badness. You've got the yin and the yang.

Well, I know what you mean there. I agree with you on this, because it's sort of no good to be handed it on a plate. I mean, just from my own experience, working for something does feel better. Because you've got a pride and a satisfaction. I genuinely think it's better to start a business, struggle, go bust, come back, than win the lottery.
Yep

I genuinely believe that. And the older I get, the more sure I am of that. That working hard is itself the reward, and I genuinely believe that. But where does it end? There's no point having the struggle till you die and never get any happiness. So... what's your balance? We'd have to go into philosophical terms here... What's your balance? What's your yin and yang of a good life? And by good life, I mean one that you've enjoyed or been satisfied with, and one that you have no regrets or guilt or shame and a bit of pride.
What are you asking me? Yeah, I've got a bit of all that.
Right
But you need the mixture, don't you? So you find out what your favorite thing is. It's like a bag of Revels.
Yeah, but you can't cherish guilt or shame.
Did you just say "Life is like a bag of revels"? Isn't that dangerously close to "Life's like a box of chocolates"?
Like Forest Gump over there, jesus...
No but it is, innit? There's one or two in there that I don't like.
Like what?
The raisin.
No no no no... Metaphorically. What's--
He actually named what Revel he doesn't like...
Well I'm telling you because it works in life.
Go on then.
You like raisins?
Well maybe- If you have enough raisin ones, you eventually go "Do you know what? They're not that bad."
What?!
And that's the thing in life.
Thing in life.
Well hold on, wait a minute. So what are you saying? Wheres this metaphor? Are you saying suddenly all the bad things in life are pretty good actually if you just get used to it?
Well sometimes, sometimes, out of bad comes some good.
Go on.
At the end of the day, the revel thing-
Mmm. What happened to the munchies?
Uh, Well, again, with life, if you have too much munchies, you get sick of the munchies. So move on. Mix it up. What mixes it up? Bag of revels. We got a bit of everything in there.
Right.
Even the ones you don't like, you might like in the end, you'll go: do you know what-
Okay, lose the analogy now. You're actually just talking about revels now in life. What about- what about... Um, what has he enjoyed before?
What would you have written to Jim'll Fix It to fix for you? What would have given you pleasure as a kid? "Dear Jim, can you fix it for me?" To do what?
Uh, when I watched Jim'll Fix It as a kid, they never really lived up to what the kid wanted, did they?
But what would you have requested?
I don't think I would, because I think I saw how disappointed most of the kids were. A kid liked whistling, they brought out Robert Whittaker!
Oh god, this is so exhausting.
Yes, because they look at it, they go, can you fix it? For me to go into space? No. Can I dance with Bananarama? No problem! That's the ones they pick. Do you know what I mean?
Yeah. That's why I wouldn't write in because whatever you ask for, you're always going to get a watered-down version.
But if Jim could fix it for you to do anything, what would you have chosen?
There's not many things I wanted as a kid.
One thing, just one thing. To choose one thing, please.
That my name was Brett.
Ricky laughs
Oh, fucking hell!
I mean, it's extraordinary.
There is no-there is no predicting that!
Okay, you know what? I can make that dream come true for you right now, Brett.
We can just call you Brett from now on.
Not a problem, Brett.
Brett Pilkington.
It sounds good.
I love the fact that it's the Karl bit he wants to replace, not the fucking Pilkington.
No, that doesn't work either Because I told my mum and dad that's what I wanted. They started calling me that, but then I forgot.
What? They went along with it?
Yeah.
So you said: "Mom, dad, call me Brett from now on," and they went, "all right."
Yeah, but then I kept forgetting that I was Brett, so I wasn't answering. So they went back to Karl.
Ricky laughs
It's amazing!
So you had that dream come true?
Yeah, and it wasn't that good, And that's what I'm saying to you. Things never live up to what you want. Dreams. What are they?
Ricky and steve laugh

Taking one of the big themes of philosophy further: Why are we here? What's the point of life? What is it to be human? Um, The ethical upshots of some of the technological and medical breakthroughs pose, you know, more of their own questions. Cloning. Is that a person in its own right? Well, of course it is. Um, What about if you grow that for harvesting without the brain-
Growing, kind of
Vital organs in a laboratory.
What about that, you know, stem cell research?
There's weird thing happening all the time with all this transplant stuff. Read about one who-- You know, a way of-- You're saying "No, it's just a bit of meat."
No, what I meant is, organs can't have rights and feelings and...
No but listen to this.
Go on. It's going to be bullshit!
No.
No No-- The sensor went... (makes beeping noise)
Would you like a small wager?
The sensors went up when he said "Right, listen to this."
Okay, I'm going to bet you Â£5 Rick, that this is not bullshit. Don't let me down, Karl!
Okay, I'm going to bet you they found out it was the heart of a chimp and the bloke suddenly liked bananas.
Okay
And the doctor bought it half price at a market.
I've got faith in Karl! I don't think he's going to let me down here. Not when we're talking about philosophy, he's gonna done some careful research. Let's take a wager! Five pounds is coming my way!

So what happened is- Do you know, like people do donor cards. Someone filled one out saying "If I die, he can have my kidney." So anyway, he died. They said "Get the kidney out!" So they got the kidney out of him. Someone who needed a new kidney... They were like over the moon, there's new kidney on the way. But this person who needed the new kidney had a couple of things... He wasn't very good at driving and he couldn't stand yellow biscuits.
Right...
Couldn't stand yellow biscuits?
Okay...
He just didn't like them. There was something- He didn't know why. He just never liked them. Anyway, they pop it in. He's having his test done, he's in hospital for a couple of days... Goes home...
Karl is smacking his lips
He goes: "I could do with a yellow biscuit."
What the fuck's a yellow biscuit?!
Just a--
Banana Baldies. What are you talking about?
Just a yellow biscuit.
Who decides "I like all biscuits except yellow ones!" Where is this... supermarket--
It just happened. And it turned out-
I don't know what the color of the biscuits got necessarily got to do with it?
It's like a phobia.
Oh, so he fears the combination of yellowness and biscuitiness!
Right, so a bloke...
He doesn't mind biscuits, I don't mind yellow. "Don't ever put them together, that's my worst nightmaaaaaare..."
Steve & Ricky laugh
So, right... I'm confused as to who's got what- Who's kidney? A bloke's received a new kidney. He hated biscuits that-
He's not very good at driving, and he hates custard creams.
Right, but now, suddenly after the hospital transport-- After the operation...
Steve smacks his lips
...I really fancy yellow biscuit.
Yeah.
Okay. Does he go out for a drive at any point?
He went driving-
He's gotta be terrible at driving.
What? He loved driving.
He liked driving all of a sudden.
What? He hated it!
I know, but this is what's weird.
It's bollocks! The kidney is a filter system.
But if you have something for long enough-
It's like getting a new tea strainer, and suddenly liking yellow biscuits and driving.
No
The kidney has no impact on anything.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
So that's, that's my point. It's just that...
What's your point?
That you can have a chat with a fella just like I'm talking to the geek at the bus stop.
(Laughs) He even pointed (At Stephen)
Sometimes, sometimes you can't take part. What am I meant to say about him meeting Reagan? What am I meant to say about.
Well aren't you interested to ask him questions about he was in a war.
When I sort of took it back to, oh I wonder what meat they're doing at the barbecue, he wasn't bothered.
(laughs) I loved the fact that that's your contribution. He's talking about the missile crisis and you're going ohhh...
He's met presidents and important people. He's experienced extraordinary things which would be fascinating to anyone and you're not interested. You just want to know whether the sausages.

I mean, there it is. You see, he's come down, he's looked at you without prejudice and thought, I don't know this guy. The language barrier probably saved you. And he thought, he's probably a smart guy. I'll tell him a bit about my life. Why ais he looking at my arse? Why is he looking at my meat and two veg? No, I, the barbecue. You don't need the barbecue, there's a lovely little fucking sausage here.
It when you're talking to a stranger. Aren't you meant to keep it.
Above the waist?
Keep it errr...
Looking at his bollocks
Keep it...
Erect? (laughs) I made Karl laugh.

Well, there you have it. The in depth study of the mother of science. The Ricky Gervais Guide to Philosophy. You can still enjoy the back catalogue of these guides: medicine, natural history and the arts and seasons one to five of the refuge of a show. Over the last few years, with all our explorations, our studies, what have you learned? What's the one big thing you've learned since we've been doing this, since you've met myself and Stephen, since we've been prodding you, since we've treated you like an ape that we want to teach to speak, What have you learned about yourself and the world? One thing, if you have to take it with you.
I don't think if I've learned anything that substantial.
Ever?

During all this? there's not been anything ground-breaking, has there? We've chatted about midgets with no arms and legs. Gay ones. I don't know if that will ever crop up again in the chat. So even if I've learned something from it, I don't think I'll ever crop up again. So it's no use. That's what I'm saying to you about information and intelligence. It's if you can use it. There's no point having a brainy head.
So you're saying this series of audiobooks at a price of Â£1.95 is absolutely worthless and pointless.
Yes, I suppose it is
Thanks, goodnight.

synopsis.description: The 'Experience machine' thought experiment, put forward by philosopher Robert Nozick.
Karl tells the story of the man suddenly liking yellow biscuits
